contexts.context: The correct interpretation of <mark>hyphens</mark> in the context of word boundaries is...
...for separate words to be connected with a <mark>hyphen</mark>: "out-of-the-box," "under-the-table," "Italian-American," and so on. A...
..."Italian-American," and so on. A significant number are <mark>hyphenated</mark> names, such as "Smith-Hawkins." When doing a...
...users expect to find the word within those <mark>hyphens</mark>. While there are some cases where they...
..."resort"), it is better overall to keep the <mark>hyphen</mark> out of the default definition. Hyphens include...
...keep the hyphen out of the default definition. <mark>Hyphens</mark> include U+002D HYPHEN-MINUS, U+2010 HYPHEN, possibly also...
...out of the default definition. Hyphens include U+002D <mark>HYPHEN</mark>-MINUS, U+2010 HYPHEN, possibly also U+058A ARMENIAN HYPHEN,...
...the default definition. Hyphens include U+002D HYPHEN-MINUS, U+2010 <mark>HYPHEN</mark>, possibly also U+058A ARMENIAN HYPHEN, and U+30A0...
...U+002D HYPHEN-MINUS, U+2010 HYPHEN, possibly also U+058A ARMENIAN <mark>HYPHEN</mark>, and U+30A0 KATAKANA-HIRAGANA DOUBLE HYPHEN.
...also U+058A ARMENIAN HYPHEN, and U+30A0 KATAKANA-HIRAGANA DOUBLE <mark>HYPHEN</mark>.
...English (and not Proto-Indo-European languages). Here's another triple <mark>hyphenated</mark> word: non-government-owned corporations. Thanks Wikipedia! Let's try...
Sometimes we use double-<mark>hyphens</mark> instead of an em-dash for whatever reason--conceivably,...
...for whatever reason--conceivably, the tokenizer should skip double <mark>hyphens</mark>.
